title: 108_s348
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" is the short title of the Act. It includes an expansion of the deduction for higher education expenses. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" expands the deduction for higher education expenses, amending the limitations on the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" increases the deduction for higher education expenses. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to $8,000 for 2003 and $12,000 for 2004 and beyond, with reductions based on modified adjusted gross income. The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with reductions starting at $8,000 for 2003 and increasing to $12,000 for 2004 and beyond. The reduction amount is determined by the taxpayer's income exceeding $65,000 ($130,000 for joint returns). The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with reductions starting at $8,000 for 2003 and increasing to $12,000 for 2004 and beyond. The reduction amount is determined by the taxpayer's income exceeding $65,000 ($130,000 for joint returns). The term 'modified adjusted gross income' excludes specific sections and is calculated after their application. "Inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2003 apply to dollar amounts in certain sections, with adjusted gross income determined without deduction allowed under this section." For taxable years after 2003, dollar amounts in subparagraph (B)(i)(II) are increased by a cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. For taxable years after 2003, dollar amounts in subparagraph (B)(i)(II) are increased by a cost-of-living adjustment. The taxable year begins by substituting `calendar year 2002' for `calendar year 1992' in subparagraph (B) thereof. Amounts adjusted under this provision are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Section 222(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended regarding the allowance of deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. Section 222(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The definition of eligible student is also clarified in the amendment. The amendments made by section 431 of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are made permanent, and the effective date for these changes is for payments made in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. An amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include a new section regarding interest on higher education loans. A credit is allowed against the tax for individuals for interest paid on qualified education loans, limited to $1,500 unless modified adjusted gross income exceeds a certain threshold. The taxpayer's allowable credit under this section is reduced if their modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns), with the reduction based on the excess income ratio to $20,000 ($40,000 for joint returns). The term 'modified adjusted gross income' excludes certain sections and is used to determine eligibility for tax credits. Inflation adjustments are made to income thresholds annually. The cost-of-living adjustment for the taxable year is determined by substituting '2002' for '1992' and rounding to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed if a deduction under section 151 is allowed for the individual. The section allows a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans during the first 60 months. Loan refinancings are treated as one loan. The section allows a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans during the first 60 months, treating loan refinancings as one loan. Definitions for "qualified education loan" and "dependent" are provided. Special rules include denial of double benefit and the requirement for married couples to file a joint return. The credit for interest paid on qualified education loans is allowed if married couples file a joint return, with marital status determined according to section 7703. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified education loans incurred before or after the enactment of the Act, with respect to loan interest payments due after December 31, 2002.
